# Question

Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

Here's the function `clean_column` in Julia that does what you want it to do. This function assumes the column name is a string. If not, it will throw an error. It also handles any other characters that are not alphanumeric, spaces, hyphens or underscores by removing them from the final result.

```julia
function clean_column(col::String)
    # Lowercase and remove leading/trailing whitespace
    col = strip(lowercase(col))

    # Replace spaces and hyphens with an underscore
    col = replace(col, r"[\s-]" => "_")

    # Remove any other characters that are not alphanumeric or an underscore
    col = replace(col, r"[^\w_]" => "")

    return col
end
```

The function takes in the column name (`col`) and returns the cleaned version of it. It uses `strip` to remove leading and trailing whitespace, `lowercase` to convert all characters to lowercase, and `replace` to replace spaces and hyphens with an underscore and remove any other non-alphanumeric or underscore characters.
